note.p: “proud venus there / Glittering in the evening air” (RF T70; MS III)—A favorite adjective of Ruskinʼs, glittering, is found applied several times to stars and constellations in one of his sources for information about astronomy, Sandford and Merton, as in “glorious, glittering bodies . . . now above us” (Day, History of Sandford and Merton, 165). However, Ruskinʼs other epithet for Venus, proud, is not typical. In poetry, Venus is more commonly admired for its beauty than for its pride. In volume 2, “On Astronomy”, of Scientific Dialogues by Jeremiah Joyce, the Tutor begins the conversation, “Of Venus”, by glossing “the most beautiful” of planets with Miltonʼs hymn to the Creatorʼs “glorious works” in Paradise Lost:

lg.l: Fairest of Stars, last in the train of Night
If better thou belong not to the dawn,
Sure pledge of day, that crownʼst the smiling Morn
With thy bright Circlet, praise him in thy Sphere
While day arises, that sweet hour of Prime.

div.p: (bk. 5, lines 166–70, in Milton, Complete Poems and Major Prose, ed. Hughes, 306)

note.p: Ruskin does draw on Miltonʼs hymn to frame his earlier poem, “The Sun”, but his sources for the astronomical knowledge in “The Constellations” remain to be identified.

In Joyceʼs “Of Venus”, the Tutor goes on to explain how Venus appears as the “Evening Star” when positioned east of the sun, and as the “Morning Star” when west of the sun—appearances resulting from the planetʼs orbit as viewed from the Earth. To illustrate these more scientific astronomical observations, here and elsewhere the Tutor quotes lines from The Excursion (1728) by David Mallet (1701/2–65) (bk. 2, lines 77–81, quoted in Joyce, Scientific Dialogues, vol. 2, “Of Astronomy”, conversation 19, 198, 202).

“belt of orion” (RF T70; MS III)—Orion (the Hunter). According to Ruskinʼs geography text, “Orion, containing his Sword and luminous Belt”, is considered one of the “most remarkable” constellations “to the naked eye or telescope”, along with “Taurus, containing the Pleiades; and Ursa Major, containing the Pointers to the North Star: all visible in our winter evenings” (Goldsmith, Grammar of General Geography, 8). Situated south of Taurus (the Bull) and Gemini (the Twins, Castor and Pollux), which are constellations in the zodiac, Orion is viewed along the celestial equator, below the ecliptic. In the northern hemisphere, it rises low on the eastern horizon during winter evenings and transits westward.

Among the most anciently named constellations, Orion is mentioned, for example, in Homerʼs Odyssey as one of the constellations that guide Odysseus (bk. 5), and he also appears to Odysseus among the dead in the underworld (bk. 11). In mythology, Orion is a great hunter. He “is represented on the globe by the figure of a man with a sword in his belt, a club in his right hand, and the skin of a lion in his left; he is said by some authors to be the son of Neptune and Euryale, a famous huntress; he possessed the disposition of his mother, became the greatest hunter in the world, and boasted that there was not any animal on the earth which he could not conquer”. However, “as a punishment for his temerity”, “in the island of Crete, accompanied by Diana and Latona in the chase, . . . he perished by the bite of a scorpion” (Jamieson, Celestial Atlas, 53). Accordingly, “he was placed among the stars, in a position directly opposite to that of the Scorpion” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 69; see Scorpio; and for other tales about the death of Orion, see Ridpath, Star Tales, 135).

div.note: p>“red mars . . . / On his throne” (RF T70; MS III)—The “dusky red appearance” of the planet Mars is commonly remarked (vol. 2, “Of Astronomy”, coversation 20, “Of Mars”, in Joyce, Scientific Dialogues, 207). The iconography of seating the Olympian gods on thrones may have been most familiar to Ruskin from the synod of the gods in book 15 of Homerʼs Iliad (in Popeʼs translation), after Jupiter has rebuked Juno for assisting the Trojans. Juno provokes Mars to resentful rage for the loss of his son, Ascalaphus. Minerva “[s]tarts from her azure throne to calm the god”, reminding him of the futility of striving against Jove, and “[t]his menace fixʼd the warrior to his throne; / Sullen he sat, and curbʼd the rising groan” (bk. 15, lines 141, 160–61). This passage also pertains to the association of Mars and Venus, Juno having conspired with Venus in book 14 to distract Jupiter from the battlefield with love‐making and sleep (Homer, Iliad, trans. Pope, 307, and see 303–7, 292–97). For Ruskinʼs 1824 edition of Popeʼs Iliad, see Books Used by Ruskin in His Youth: Physical Descriptions. For the possibility that the poemʼs configuration of Venus, Mars, and Orion could have been based on real‐life observation, see the “The Constellations” apparatus: Discussion—Real‐life Observations.

note.p: “the greater bear is seen / Then charlesʼs wain with his bright team” (RF T70; MS III)—Turning back from a planet to the constellations, Ruskin begins with the largest circumpolar constellation, Ursa Major (the Great Bear), which contains the oblong configuration of four stars also known as the Plough or Charlesʼs Wain, with another three stars forming its “team” of horses. In both Dayʼs History of Sandford and Merton and Joyceʼs Scientific Dialogues, the pupils are shown stars in the Plough or Wain that serve as “pointers” to the North Star, enabling the boys to determine compass bearings in the dark. As Joyceʼs Tutor explains, “if you wish to be a young astronomer”, a youth “must learn to find these [cardinal compass] points without the assistance of the sun”; and he directs their eyes to “those seven stars which are in the constellation of the Great Bear”, which “some people have supposed . . . aptly represent a plough; others say, that they are more like a waggon and horses;—the four stars representing the body of the waggon, and the other three the horses” (Joyce, Scientific Dialogues, vol. 2, “Of Astronomy”, conversation 2, “Of the Fixed Stars”, 15–16; see also Crux (the Southern Cross)).

Considered as part of the larger constellation, the seven stars “form a quadrilateral figure in the back of the Bear; the other three stars project from one of the angles in a curved line, and constitute the tail”; however, the seven stars “occupy but a small part of the whole constellation, which is one of the most extensive in the heavens” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 23). Among the oldest named constellations in classical sources familiar to Ruskin, the Great Bear is mentioned along with Orion by Homer in the Odyssey (bk. 5), and as ever‐present in the sky, never bathing in the sea. The best‐known story in western classical poetry about the Great Bear is told by Ovid in Metamorphoses. The nymph Callisto, a companion of the huntress Artemis [Diana] is raped by Zeus [Jupiter]. Unable to conceal her pregnancy, Callisto is shunned by Artemisʼs chaste band, and she becomes prey to the revenge of Hera [Juno]. She is saved by metamorphosis into a bear, only to be hunted by Artemis as well as by Callistoʼs own unwitting son by Zeus, Arcas. Zeus rescues Callisto from this predicament by setting her in heaven as a constellation (Ridpath, Star Tales, 172–74, and see 174–75 for other stories; see also Ursa Minor, below).

“the dragon“ (RF T70; MS III)—Also a circumpolar constellation, Draco (the Dragon) winds around the North Star (Polaris) between Ursa Major (the Great Bear) and Cepheus. It is among the forty‐eight constellations listed by Ptolemy.

In mythology, “[b]y some writers the Dragon is represented as the monster which protected the golden apples in the garden of Hesperides, and which was slain by Hercules [Heracles]. Juno [Hera], who presented these apples to Jupiter [Zeus] on their nuptials, took Draco up into heaven, and made of it this constellation, as a reward for its faithful services. It has since become an emblem of vigilance. Others maintain, that in a war with the Giants, this Dragon was brought into the combat, and opposed to Minerva [Athena], who threw it round the axis of the earth before it had time to uncoil, where it remains to this day” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 23). Jamieson summarizes the same legends and adds: “Whoever attends to the situation of Draco, surrounding the Pole of the Ecliptic, will perceive that its tortuous folds are symbolical of the oblique course of the stars” (Celestial Atlas, 18). Hercules, who slew the dragon as one of his labors, has his own constellation nearby. Ridpath draws on Hesiod and the Bibliotheca of Apollodorus for versions of the story (Star Tales, 92).

“berenices golden hair“ (RF T70; MS III)—Coma Berenices (Bereniceʼs Hair) is situated between Ursa Major and Boötes and south of Canes Venatici (the Hunting Dogs)—or, as Green specifies, referring to a star in Canes Venatici, “[a] little to the south of Cor Caroli [Charlesʼs Heart]” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 52). Eratosthanes and Ptolemy represented the asterism as the hair of famous women, but counted its stars among the constellation Leo (the Lion), and it was not treated as a separate constellation until the sixteenth century (Ridpath, Star Tales, 78).

Green describes “[t]his remarkable cluster of minute stars” as “shin[ing] with a light somewhat like that of the Milky Way”; and he goes on to relay the story as told by the Latin writer, Hyginus, about a historical, third‐century B.C. Egyptian woman, Berenice. She “married her own brother, Evergestes, one of the kings of Egypt, whom she loved with much tenderness. Upon an important occasion, having left her to engage in a dangerous enterprise, she vowed to dedicate to Venus [Aphrodite] her hair, which was extremely beautiful, if he should be restored to her in safety. Some time after his victorious return, the locks which had been deposited in the temple of Venus, according to her oath, disappeared. The king expressing great regret for their loss, Connon, his astronomer, publicly reported that Jupiter [Zeus] had taken them away and placed them among the stars. Being sent for by Evergestes, Connon pointed out this constellation, saying, ‘There, behold the locks of the queen’. As this group was not before on the maps, being among the unformed stars until that time, this satisfied the king of the truth of Connonʼs declaration” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 52). Ridpath clarifies that the historical Berenice of Egypt married her cousin, Ptolemy III, not her brother (Star Tales, 79). Bereniceʼs hair is depicted as golden in plate VII of Jamiesonʼs Celestial Atlas but as brown on card 10 of the boxed set of constellation cards, Uraniaʼs Mirror, which were copied from Jamiesonʼs plates, although, as Ridpath remarks, the sets of hand‐colored cards were not uniform (“Uraniaʼs Mirror”, accessed 2 June 2023).

“the northern crown“ (RF T70; MS III)—Corona Borealis (the Northern Crown) appears between Boötes and Hercules. It was included in Ptolemyʼs list of forty‐eight constellations, and “may very easily be known by the circular form of its principal stars, which are six in number. A crown or garland may readily be imagined from the striking arrangement of the whole group” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 49).

The mythology, according to Green, commemorates “a crown presented by Bacchus [Dionysius] to Ariadne, the daughter of Minos, second king of Crete. Theseus, king of Athens, was shut up in the celebrated labyrinth of Crete, erected by Daedalus, to be devoured by Minotaur; but he slew the monster, and being furnished with a clew by Ariadne, who was passionately attached to him, made his escape from the intricate windings of his place of confinement. He afterwards married Ariadne, but soon treated her in the most cruel manner, so that she was induced, according to some writers, to commit suicide. After her death the crown of stars given by Bacchus was made this constellation” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 49).
Theseusʼs mistreatment consisted in abandoning her on the island of Naxos. According to other versions of the story, as noted in Jamiesonʼs brief telling, Bacchus rescues and marries her (Ridpath, Star Tales, 82; Jamieson, Celestial Atlas, 27).

“the very fiery swan“ (RF T70; MS III)—Cygnus (the Swan), or Northern Cross, lies south of Draco, between Cepheus and Hercules. It was included in the forty‐eight constellations listed by Ptolemy. The constellation “may very easily be recognised”, Green says, “as its principal stars form a large and regular cross in the Milky Way, from which circumstance the whole group is often called the Cross”. Perhaps because the stars forming Cygnus occur within an area of the Milky Way that both Green and Jamieson describe as “remarkably brilliant” with a “peculiar degree of brightness”, Ruskin decided to revise the epithet for Swan to “fiery” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 43; Jamieson, Celestial Atlas, 32).

In Jamiesonʼs telling, closely mirrored by Green, “Orpheus, the celebrated musician of antiquity, having been killed by the cruel priestess of Bacchus, the gods metamorphosed him into a Swan, and placed him among the stars by the side of his lyre”, referring to the constellation Lyra (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 44). Vaguely referring to “considerable doubt” in the legends connected with the Swan, Green omits mention of the myth which Jamieson relates prior to the Orpheus story, identifying the swan as Zeusʼs disguise for committing rape. In some stories, the victim was the nymph Nemesis, and in other stories she was the queen of Sparta, Leda. Jamieson considers as one person “Leda or Nemesis, the wife of Tyndarus, king of Laconia” (the region surrounding Sparta). While delicately referring to the rape as a deception, Jamieson makes clear that offspring resulted: “Leda was the mother of Pollux and Helena, the most beautiful woman of her age, and also of Castor and Clytemnestra. The two former were deemed the offspring of Jupiter, and the others claimed Tyndarus as their father” (Celestial Atlas, 32). Ridpath adds that the story of Nemesis is also connected with the nearby constellation, Aquila (the Eagle), which was the shape taken by Aphrodite while pretending to chase Jupiter [Zeus] disguised as the Swan into the arms of the nymph (Ridpath, Star Tales, 86–87, 44).

“starry charlesʼs heart“ (RF T70; MS III)—Cor Caroli (Charlesʼs Heart) is a star in the constellation Canes Venatici (the Hunting Dogs). The constellation, which lies between Boötes and Ursa Major, was introduced by the Polish astronomer Johannes Hevelius in 1687, more than a decade after the star was named and then first published on a star chart of 1673 (Ridpath, Star Tales, 59–60). In the 1820s, Green illustrated the star by itself, shining independently of an outline of the Hunting Dogs constellation, on the chart devoted primarily to the Great Bear, whereas Jamieson showed the the star positioned over top of the collar of one of the dogs. Both picture the star as a red heart topped by a crown (Green, Astronomical Recreations, pl. 2; ). Celestial Atlas, pl. 7).

The star was first named Cor Caroli Regis Martyris “in honour of Charles I” by “Sir Charles Scarborough [1615–94], physician to Charles II” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 31). A legend held that the star blazed brightly on the day in May 1660 when Charles II rode into London to restore the Stuart monarchy. Early in the nineteenth century, a German astronomer, Johann Bode (1747–1826), misattributed the naming of the star to the English astronomer, Edmond Halley (1656–1742), and moved its invention forward into the eighteenth century; independently, another error identified the starʼs namesake as Charles II. The starʼs proper origin, however, lies in the seventeenth century with those who regarded Charles I as a martyr (Warner, letter to the editor; Ridpath, Star Tales, 60). See also Charlesʼs Oak, below, which Halley did name after Charles II.

“Then the dread medusas head” and “After that the telescope” (RF T70; MS III)—Ruskinʼs original choice for this line, Caput Medusae (Medusaʼs Head), was anciently a part of the constellation representing Medusaʼs conqueror, Perseus, one of the forty‐eight constellations listed by Ptolemy. However, the Medusa Head was labeled separately as a constellation in itself in some charts produced between the seventeenth and nineteenth centuries (Star Tales, 143). Jamieson treats the two constellations as a unit (Celestial Atlas, 19). Ruskinʼs decision to replace the Medusaʼs Head—perhaps because decapitation was deemed too gruesome and pagan in the Ruskin household—did not immediately shift his attention to the larger constellation, Perseus, which is inseperable from the bloody legend. Whether as one constellation or two, “Perseus is represented on the celestial maps with a sword in his right hand and the head of Medusa in his left”, as Green remarks (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 36).

Despite the erasure of Caput Medusae (Medusaʼs Head), the Gorgon seems to haunt the poem, since Perseus is listed later in combination with Pegasus, which sprang from Medusaʼs body when slain by Perseus. See the constellations Perseus and Pegasus.

In place of Medusaʼs Head, Ruskin turned to a constellation bordering Perseus, one that in his time was a comparatively recent creaton, and that suggested the modernity of science rather than ancient blood feuds. Telescopium Herschelii (Herschelʼs Telescope) is now an obsolete constellation, but Jamieson and Green acknowledged it in 1822 and 1824 respectively (Jamieson, Celestial Atlas, 22; Green, Astronomical Recreations, 33).

Telescopium Herschelii was created in 1789 by the Hungarian astronomer, Maximilian Hell (1720–92), who devised it from “a few of the stars of Auriga [the Charioteer]. . . . It is intended to perpetuate the name of Herschell [William Herschel, 1738–1822] and the form of the instrument by which he discovered the planet Uranus in the year 1781” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 33).

Ridpath explains that Hell originally created two constellations commemorating Herschel telescopes, which were reduced to one by Johann Bode in 1801. Presumably, Ruskin intended Telescopium Herschelii, and not yet another constellation on the same theme, Telescopium (Telescope), which is a small formation in the southern hemisphere, and which remains an officially recognized constellation today. It was created by the French astronomer, Nicolas‐Louis de Lacaille (1713–62); and while there is no way to prove Ruskinʼs intent, it is reasonable to assume that he meant to celebrate the constellation honoring the British astronomer (see Star Tales, 205–6, 167–68).

“the little horse“ (RF T70; MS III)—Equuleus (Little Horse) is positioned south of Cygnus (the Swan) and Delphinus (the Dolphin), and next to its vastly larger and more famous relative, Pegasus. Equuleus was included in Ptolemyʼs list of forty‐eight constellations.

This very small constellation represents only the head of a horse named, “according to the Poets, . . . Celeris, given by Mercury to Castor, who was celebrated for his skill in the management of this noble animal” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 59).

“the stupid goose“ (RF T70; MS III)—Ruskin lists Anser (the Goose) singly, separated from its predator in the paired constellation, Vulpecula et Anser (Fox and Goose); see Vulpecula. Vulpecula et Anser “crosses the Milky Way a littie to the south of Cygnus, and to the north of the Arrow [Sagitta]” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 48).

Vulcepula et Anser was introduced by the Polish astronomer, Johannes Hevelius (1611–87), who depicted it as a fox with a goose captured in its jaws. The haplessness of the bird may account for Ruskinʼs epithet of “stupid”, but by dividing the constellation in two Ruskin also avoids drawing attention to the gooseʼs fate. A precedent for separating the fox from the goose extends back to Hevelius himself, who named the constellation both as a single entity, Vulpecula cum Anser, and as two distinct entities, which were afterward sometimes reunited as Vulpecula et Anser. Nowadays, the goose is omitted altogether, leaving only Vulpecula (Ridpath, Star Tales, 182–83).

Perhaps a predatory and carnivorous fox offended nineteenth‐century sensibility, since Green omits any mention of what is happening to the goose. Ruskin not only separates the constellations, but also places Lepus (the Hare) between them. If he intended to shield the goose from the fox, he undercut the effort by giving the hare the epithet “timid” (“frightened” in RF T70).

“After that doth come the lyre” and “After that doth come the very timid hare“ (RF T70; MS III)—Lepus (the Hare) is south of Orion, just below the celestial equator, and therefore counts among “some of the southern” constellations declared in Ruskinʼs title of his poem. Lepus is one of the forty‐eight constellations listed by Ptolemy.

“The Hare seems to have been placed at the feet of Orion in compliment to his skill in the chase” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 98). Ridpath adds that some mythographers viewed the nearby dog constellations, Canis Major and Canis Minor, as helping in Orionʼs chase of the hare. The stories that Ridpath summarizes about the hare suggest that it was read less with mythological associations than with moral and animal tales (Star Tales, 115–16).

Ruskinʼs original choice for this line, Lyra (the Lyre), is a northern constellation positioned between Cygnus and Hercules, far from Lepus which replaced Lyra. The Lyre was among the forty‐eight constellations listed by Ptolomy, and it was associated with the story of Orpheus. Jamieson drew the Lyre on his plate VIII as “a copy of the instrument in the famous ancient picture dug out of Herculaneum, upon which Chiron is teaching young Achilles to play” (the fresco of Chiron and Achilles, Villa of the Papyri); and he speculates that the constellation was inspired by the notion of the music of the spheres (Jamieson, Celestial Atlas, 28). See also Delphinus (the Doplphin) for Lyre and the story of Arion.

The constellation is also known as Vultur et Lyra (Vulture and Harp), “often depicted on star maps as a bird positioned behind a lyre”. Ridpath explains that the name of the constellationʼs very bright star, Vega, “comes from . . . Arabic words . . . which can mean either ‘the swooping eagle’ or ‘vulture’, for the Arabs saw both an eagle and a vulture here” (Star Tales, 122; and see Green, Astronomical Recreations, 44–45).
See the textual note for speculation about why, in RF T70, Ruskin deleted Lyra (the Lyre) in this line and substituted a different constellation.

“the lesser bear“ (RF T70; MS III)—Ursa Minor (the Lesser Bear) is a circumpolar constellation containing Polaris (the Pole Star), which forms the tip of his tail. It was one of the forty‐eight constellations listed by Ptolemy.

“Ursa Minor, according to ancient Greek tradition, became a constellation in memory of Arcas, the son of Callisto and grandson of the cruel Lycaon, king of Arcadia. The current opinion is, that Arcas was changed by Jupiter [Zeus] into a bear, and placed here in the heavens; but it is thought by others, with more probability we think, that this was done by Juno [Hera] (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 21–22; Jamieson, however, seems to associate this story with Ursa Major [Celestial Atlas, 24). According to another myth, Ursa Minor is one of the nymphs who nursed the infant Zeus (Ridpath, Star Tales, 177). See Boötes
“the cunning fox“ (RF T70; MS III)—For the invention and location of Vulpecula (the Fox), see Anser (the Goose).

“the blessed cross“ (RF T70; MS III)—Unless Ruskin mistook as a separate constellation what “is often called the Cross” or Northern Cross—which is a common name for Cygnus (the Swan), but which he has already listed (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 43; Ridpath, Star Tales, 85)—here he refers to Crux (the Cross, or Southern Cross), and thus for the first time in the poem names a southern constellation. Crux is made up of “four fine stars near the hind feet of the Centaur [Centaurus], . . . which are among the most brilliant in southern latitudes” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 102). Jamieson adds that “the most Northerly and Southerly” of these four stars “are always in a line with the South Pole. They are therefore the Pointers for discerning, in the Southern hemisphere, the Antarctic pole” (Jamieson, Celestial Atlas, 63, pl. 28).

These stars were known to Ptolemy, but he considered them as part of Centaurus in his catalogue of forty‐eight constellations. As Ridpath explains, although visible to the ancient Mediterranean world, the stars were lost to view in the north owing to precession in the Earthʼs rotational axis. The stars were rediscovered and charted by European explorers sailing south in the sixteenth century, and it came to be used by navigators since its axis points to the southern pole (Ridpath, Star Tales, 84–85). The Southern Cross would never have been visible to Ruskin.

“great charlesʼs oak“ (RF T70; MS III)—Robur Carolinum (Charlesʼs Oak) was also a southern constellation, which would never have been visible to Ruskin. Could his plunge to Crux have been aimed at this Carolingian constellation, which is adjacent to the Southern Cross? The next departure from the northern constellations, the plunge south to Apus, may also have been drawn by British associations.

Robur Carolinum (Charlesʼs Oak) is now obsolete, eliminated by a star survey undertaken from the Cape of Good Hope by the French astronomer, Nicolas‐Louis de Lacaille (1713–62), who then excluded the British honorific constellation from his catalogue published in 1763. Nonethelesss, Ridpath remarks, Johann Bode retained the constellation in his 1801 star chart (Ridpath, Star Tales, 202–3).

Charlesʼs Oak was also treated as an existing constellation by both Jamieson and Green in the 1820s. Greenʼs account, slightly expanded from Jamiesonʼs, alters the spelling from Robur Caroli to Rober Caroli: “Rober Caroli, or Charlesʼs Oak, is to the east of Argo Navis (Argo, the ship of Jason and the Argonauts), and contains one star of the first magnitude. Dr. [Edmond] Halley introduced this asterism on the maps in 1676, when he was in the Island of St. Helena. He named it in honour of the oak whose branches concealed Charles II after the battle of Worcester” (Green, Astronomical Recreations, 103; and see Jamieson, Celestial Atlas, 61). This battle represented the decisive defeat of Royalist forces in the English Civil War, during which the son of the executed king, Charles I, saved his life by hiding in an oak tree. After Charles II was restored to the throne, the purpose of his astronomer, Halley, in traveling to St. Helena was, like Lacaille on his mission, to survey the southern sky, and he published his star catalogue, including the new honorific constellation, in 1679 (Ridpath, Star Tales, 202). For another seventeenth‐century politically motivated invention, which has survived attempts at obsolescence, see Scutum.

“Iʼll call it junoʼs cup“ (RF T70; MS III)—Crater (the Cup) is a southern constellation, clustered together with Corvus (the Crow) and Hydra (the Water Snake), which are north of Centaurus. Ruskinʼs inclusion of Crater is mysterious, unless he regarded it as lying on the path north from Charlesʼs Oak to Hercules, skipping over Virgo on the equinoctial between them—Virgo being saved for later, since she belongs to the Zodiac.

While Ruskin may “call it junoʼs cup”, the best‐known myth associates the cup with Apollo, who gave it to Corvus (Crow) to fetch water. The crowʼs procrastination and attempted cover‐up lead Apollo to toss the cup, the water‐snake Hydra, and crow itself into heaven (Ridpath, Star Tales, 82–83). This tale is not mentioned by Jamieson, however, for whom Craterʼs appearance with with the ancient summer solstice evoked a “fable which attributes this goblet to Bacchus, . . . a finely allegorized symbol of Noahʼs planing the vine” (Celestial Atlas, 61; and see Gen. 9:20). Green also omits the Apollo and Crow tale, instead following Jamiesonʼs association of Crater with Bacchus and the “symbol of the cultivation of the vine by Noah”, and he adds the “cup of oblivion of the Platonists” (Astronomical Recreations, 101).

“Hercules appeareth high“ (RF T70; MS III)—The constellation Hercules or Heracles indeed appears higher in the sky than the previous three constellations Ruskin has listed, which are southern and below the celestial equator. Hercules stands on the head of Draco (the Dragon) and between Lyra (the Lyre) and Corona Borealis (Northern Crown). With Hercules, along with the now obsolete constellation Cerberus, Ruskin returns into the northern sky from the preceding brief sojourn among the southern constellations. The constellation was listed by Ptolemy among his forty‐eight.

Ridpath remarks that this ancient constellation was known to the poet Aratus only as the kneeling one, and that he was identified belatedly with Heracles by Eratosthenes (Star Tales, 101). In Jamiesonʼs drawing of Heracles, he “endeavoured to combine” attributes that previous star maps associated with the figure, by placing in the grip of the left hand the “Apple Branch” of the Hesperides coiled with the three‐headed, dog‐faced Cerberus, and retaining in the right hand the traditional club; and to complete the ensemble, he “added the bow and quiver of arrows” (Celestial Atlas, 27, and see pl. 8). Jamiesonʼs claim to originality was evidently exaggerated, since, according to Ridpath, in 1721 an English cartographer, John Senex (1678–1740), combined the branch of golden apples with the three‐headed serpent to form the constellation Cerberus et Ramus, which then appeared in Heraclesʼs hand in Johann Bodeʼs Uranographia (1801) (Star Tales, 190). The latter appears to be the source of Greenʼs rendering, which lacks Jamiesonʼs addition of the archery gear.

Green unpacks this representation with an ethical interpretation of the hero “celebrated in antiquity for his heroic valour and corporal strength. He is represented in a kneeling posture, holding in his right hand a club, and in his left the Hesperidian branch, with the three‐headed Cerberus; the skin of a lion covers his head and shoulders. This is the lion he killed in the forests in the neighbourhood of NemÆa, and the celebrated NemÆan games were instituted to commemorate that event. [The astronomer] Hevelius first placed in the hand of this hero the serpent with three heads, or Cerberus. The Hesperidian branch, bearing the golden apples, is probably of a more ancient date. . . . Hercules, among many other achievements, . . . procured some of these golden apples from the Hesperides, by killing the Dragon [Draco]. . . . [i]t is stated by the mythologists, that he brought upon earth the three‐headed monster Cerberus, which guarded the entrance to Plutoʼs dominions. The victory which he obtained over Cerberus, is thought by some to denote his control over his bad passions; for he is held out by the ancients as a pattern of virtue and piety. His judicious choice of virtue, in preference to pleasure, is admirably described by Xenophon” (Astronomical Recreations, 46–47).

Jamieson proposes a more complex allegory, which he integrates with the constellationʼs astronomical season: “The Three Headed Cerberus, like the triform Hecate, was a lunar symbol, and Cerberus brought back to the day by Hercules, in his 12th labour, appears to some, as an astronomical fable, relating to the arrival of the Sun in Scorpius, or Lesha, at the autumnal equinox. Thus Hercules is rendered partly an historical and partly an allegorical personage; and this combination is obviously the basis of the ingenious and elegant mythology of the Greeks. . . . If Cerberus be considered allegorically as the symbol of the earth, or more properly of all‐devouring time, his three months will represent the present, past, and future. The victory which Hercules obtained over this monster is thought to denote the conquest this hero acquired over his passions” (Celestial Atlas, 27).

“cerberus in the sky“ (RF T70; MS III)—See Hercules. That Ruskin lists Cerberus separately from Hercules tells us little about his source, since even Jamieson labels his combined constellation as “Hercules, Cerberus, and the Apple Branch”, plus he retains Senexʼs “Cerberus et Ramus” on his plate (Celestial Atlas, 27, pl. 8). As a distinct constellation, Cerberus was created by Johannes Hevelius, but from its invention the astronomer placed the creature safely in the grip of Hercules. Cerberus is now obsolete as a constellation (Star Tales, 190).

“The lizard“ (RF T70; MS III)—Lacerta (the Lizard) is between Cygnus and Andromeda. The constellation was introduced by Johannes Hevelius in 1687, and augmented with a few more stars by an English astronomer, John Flamsteed (1646–1719), in a posthumous publication of 1725 (Ridpath, Star Tales, 111–12).

“the pouncing eagle“ (RF T70; MS III)—Aquila (the Eagle) lies on the celestial equator, “on the edge of the Milky Way, south of the Swan [Cygnus] and the Arrow [Sagitta]” (Astronomical Recreations, 55). The constellation is among the forty‐eight listed by Ptolemy.

Unlike Green, Jamieson treats Aquila et Antinöus as a single constellation, a reading that Green admits reluctantly, “some writers assert[ing] that the figure which accompanies the Eagle is not Antinous, but Ganymede; thus referring the whole to one of the exploits of Jupiter”. Jamieson is more forward in identifying the eagle “as that whose form Jupiter assumed when he carried to mount Ida the beautiful Ganymede”, just as Antinöus “was a great favourite of the emperor Adrian [i.e., Hadrian]” (Jamieson, Celestial Atlas, 30; Green, Astronomical Recreations, 57). See Antinous, which Ruskin separates widely from Aquila in the poem just as he splits Anser (the Goose) and Vulpecula.

Green gives an account of Antinous similar to Jamiesonʼs, but his history of Aquila is more varied: “Some of the Poets say that this constellation represents the Eagle which brought nectar to Jupiter [Zeus] while he lay concealed in the cave at Crete [i.e., the cave in Mount Ida], to avoid the fury of his father, Saturn [Cronus]. Besides this important service, Aquila also assisted him by furnishing weapons [i.e., thunderbolts] in his victory over the giants. According to other writers, this Eagle is the same as that whose form Jupiter assumed, when he bore away Ganymede to serve as his cupbearer. Others imagine that this constellation is to commemorate the bird which preyed upon the vitals of Prometheus” (Astronomical Recreations, 56; and see Ridpath, Star Tales, 44; and see Ara (the Altar) and Auriga [the Charioteer]).

“Cepheus“ (MS IA; RF T70; MS III)—Cepheus is not only northern but circumpolar for Britons. As Jamieson observed in 1822: “Cepheus never sets to the inhabitants of London; and the chief part of his head is vertical to Scotland, as it passes over that country when on the meridional above the Pole” (Jamieson, Celestial Atlas, 18). Cepheus lies between Draco and Cassiopeia. It is “in the space between the Pole star and the Milky Way” (Astronomical Recreations, 24). The constellation is among the forty‐eight listed by Ptolemy.

“This constellation immortalizes the name of an ancient king, who reigned either in Ethiopia or India. As the Greeks called by the name of India all that part of the earth lying beyond the Mediterranean sea, it is rendered doubtful in which of the two places he lived. The name of his queen was Cassiopeia, and they were the parents of Andromeda” (Astronomical Recreations, 24). Expanding on the story of Andromeda, Ridpath explains that Cassiopeia was a boastful woman, whose vanity led her to the hubris of declaring herself more beautiful than the sea nymphs, the Nereids. The nymphs complained to their father, Poseidon (Neptune), who in retribution sent a sea monster, Cetus, to ravage Cepheusʼs kingdom. To appease the beast, Cepheus chained Andromeda to a rock by the sea as a sacrifice, but she was saved by Perseus who defeated the monster and took Andromeda as his wife (Star Tales, 72–73). See Perseus; Caput Medusae (Medusaʼs Head); Pegasus; and Andromeda. Ruskin does not include the constellations Cassiopeia or Cetus, the Sea Monster, in his poem.

“bootes” (MS IA; RF T70; MS III)—Boötes is bordered by Corona Borealis (the Northern Crown), Cor Caroli (Charlesʼs Heart), Coma Berenices (Bereniceʼs Hair), Canes Venatici (Hunting Dogs), and the constellation with which its legends are most closely associated, Ursa Major (the Great Bear). “When examined in the sky, [Boötes] . . . seems to be a continuation of the tail of Ursa Major” (Astronomical Recreations, 50).

Ridpath explains that the name “probably comes from a Greek word meaning ‘noisy’ or ‘clamorous’, referring to the herdsmanʼs shouts to his animals”; or, linking the etymology to Charlesʼs Wain inside Ursa Major, the name is a word “from the ancient Greek meaning ‘ox‐driver’“ According to a legend in Eratosthenes similar to a story associated with Ursa Minor, the constellation “represents Arcas, son of the god Zeus and his paramour Callisto, daughter of King Lycaon of Arcadia”. His mother was turned into a bear, whom Arcas encountered when hunting. “Callisto recognized her son, but though she tried to greet him warmly she could only growl. . . . Zeus snatched up Arcas and his mother and placed them in the sky as the constellations of the bear‐keeper and the bear” (Ridpath, Star Tales, 53).

In 1822, Jamieson likewise noted that Boötes is pulled toward conflicting identities. As Arcas the hunter, he “appears in a walking posture, grasping in his right hand a spear, and having his left extended upwards, holding the leash of the dogs Asterion and Chara [Canes Venatici], which seem to be barking at the Great Bear”. As the Wagoner, he appears to drive Charlesʼs Wain, as illustrated by lines that Jamieson quotes from James Thomsonʼs The Seasons: “Wide oʼer the spacious regions of the North, / Boötes urges on his tardy wain” (slightly misquoted from lines 834–35 of Winter, in Thomson, “The Seasons” and “The Castle of Indolence”, ed. Sambrook, 151; Jamieson, Celestial Atlas, 25; see also Auriga).

“sweet hirundo“ (MS IA; RF T70; MS III)—Again, Ruskin appears to have dipped into the southern constellations in order to retrieve a star formation with British associations, in this case one with an English name, the Swallow (see also Robur Carolinum (Charlesʼs Oak)). The name “swallow” appears in the first draft, MS IA, and in the fair copy, RF T70. In the latter, Ruskin struck through the name and substituted “sweet hirundo”, which he carried over to the final fair copy, MS III. Neither of these names is used—either in todayʼs star charts or in Jamiesonʼs chart published in Ruskinʼs time—where the constellation is called Apus or Apus Indica or (in English) Bird of Paradise (Jamieson, Celestial Atlas, 63, pl. 28).

The constellation, which is associated with the family of exotic birds commonly known as birds of paradise, was one among twelve southern constellations introduced to European sky charts in the late sixteenth century, based on observations of the sky south of the equator the Dutch navigators, Pieter Dirkszoon Keyser and Frederick de Houtman. The name Apus was derived from the Greek for without foot, since, as Ridpath explains, specimens originally obtained from New Guinea by Europeans were skins from which the birdsʼ feet had been removed, leading to speculation that these fabulous birds, with their long and colorful plummage, remained permanently in flight (Ridpath, Star Tales, 41).

According to Richard Hinckley Allen, the constellation may have acquired the name, the Swallow, by way of the common English name for Linnaeusʼs species name, Hirundo apus, which is also applied to the swift‐birds associated with the approach of summer (Allen, Star Names, 44). It is not clear, however, that Ruskin identified the Swallow or Hirundo with the constellation Apus at all. These two constellations are listed separately in An Introduction to Astronomy Intended for Little Children (1817) by Mrs. Sherwood (1775–1851). In her list, “The New Constellations to the South of the Ecliptic”, “Hirundo, the Swallow” appears between “Grus, the Crane” and “Indus, the Indian”, while “Apus, or Avis Indica, the Bird of Paradise” appears at the end of the list, following “Triangulum Australe, the Southern Triangle”. Sherwoodʼs list is not necessarily ordered according to juxtaposition of constellations on a map, so it is unclear what constellation she signifies as the Swallow; and while Ruskin is not known to have used this book, the list may point to confusion over southern constellations invisible to northern viewers, yet a will to Anglicize naming the night sky where possible (Sherwood, Introduction to Astronomy, 17).

“Maenalus mountain“ (MS IA; RF T70; MS III)—Returning to northern constellations, one finds “beneath the feet of Bootes is Mons Menalus, a mountain in Arcadia, and which received its name from Menalus, a son of Lycaon. This mountain, according to mythologists, was sacred to Pan, and was frequented by shepherds” (Astronomical Recreations, 51; see Boötes; Ursa Major).

Ripath remarks that this constellation, another of those introduced by Johannes Hevelius in 1687, never became independent of Boötes standing on it and is now obsolete. In Metamorphoses, Ovid describes Mons Maenalus as a haunt of Diana and her hunters, including Callisto (Ridpath, Star Tales, 198).

“the furious keen‐eyed lynx“ (MS IA; RF T70; MS III)—The faint stars in the patch of sky that Lynx occupies between Ursa Major and Auriga were listed by Ptolomy among the “unformed” stars outside of the Great Bear. From these faint stars Hevelius in 1687 formed Lynx, a beast possibly chosen to glorify the astronomerʼs naked eyesight, on which Hevelius continued to rely when other astronomers had turned to instruments. “Anyone who wanted to observe” this constellation, he wrote, “would need the eyesight of a lynx” (Ridpath, Star Tales, 119–20). Intentionally or not, Ruskinʼs epithet carries forward this association.

Jamieson remarks that “the greater part” of Lynx “does not . . . set to the British Isles” and the starsʼ “positions may be easily ascertained by reference to the neighbouring constellations” (Celestial Atlas, 23. Unimpressed, Green considered Lynxwondered “a very uninteresting constellation” and wondered “why a Lynx should have been chosen to represent this cluster of stars, rather than any other animal” (Astronomical Recreations, 32).

“High up there is scorpio“ (MS IA; RF T70; MS III)—With Scorpio, Ruskin begins naming the constellations of the Zodiac—the constellations that lie within the apparent path of the sun—as promised in the poemʼs title.

In the northern hemisphere, Scorpio (Scorpion), despite Ruskinʼs epithet, is not “high”, its tail never appearing above the horizon in London, according to Jamieson. For nineteenth‐century British observers, Scorpio was considered a late autumn sign, Jamieson dating the sunʼs entry into its path on November 20. It is situated opposite in the sky to Orion, rising as the latter sets, thus presenting a germ of its myth, since Scorpioʼs sting caused the death of the hunter. As Jamieson summarizes the stories, both mythological and naturalistic, the Scorpion was sent by Diana “to wound Orion for usurping her office. Ovid tells us that this serpent was produced by the Earth, to punish Orionʼs vanity for having boasted that there was not on the terraqueous globe any animal which he could not conquer. Again, it is said that Autumn, which produces fruits in great abundance, brings with it a variety of diseases; and this season is very fitly represented by a Scorpion, which wounds with its tail as it recedes” (Jamieson, Celestial Atlas, 45; see Ridpath, Star Tales, 157; see also Orion).

“the generous leo“ (MS IA; RF T70; MS III)—Leo (the Lion), like Scorpio (the Scorpion), is a constellation of the Zodiac, but they are not otherwise obviously related, except in their ferocity as creatures. Leo is the fifth sign of the Zodiac, and Scorpio the eighth; and Leo is a northern constellation, the second sign of summer, Jamieson reckoning its influence in 1822 as beginning on August 8, as compared with Scorpio, which is a southern constellation, the second sign of Autumn (Jamieson, Celestial Atlas, 40).

Ruskinʼs first epithet, “king”, as drafted in MS IA and fair‐copied in RF T70, is more appropriate to Leoʼs mythological associations than his second epithet, “generous”, as substituted in RF T70 and fair‐copied in MS III. As Jamieson summarizes, “[p]opular tradition represents the Lion, an animal remarkable for his fierceness and strength, as emblematical of the Sunʼs heat at this period of the year” in advanced summer (Celestial Atlas, 40).

Mythologically, Leo is associated with the terrible Lion of Nemea, which Hercules defeated as the first of his twelve labors. After Hercules was sucessful, he made a cloak of the Lionʼs skin, which was said to be impervious to weapons, and the lionʼs head of the cloak rested atop Herculesʼs own head (Ridpath, Star Tales, 112).

Green uses the constellation to highlight the Zodiac of Dendera, an artifact removed from an ancient building by Napoleonʼs agents during the campaign in Egypt, and brought to Paris to be installed in the Royal Library (Green says the Louvre) in 1822. Green notes that the constellations carved on the disk start from Leo, rather than from Aries, normally treated as the first sign of the Zodiac owing to its association with the vernal equinox. Writing on the constellation Aries, Green is skeptical of “those who are desirous of drawing from every source an argument against the chronology of the Bible, that these zodiacs were constructed when the sun entered the sign Leo, which must have been more than ten thousand years before the birth of our Saviour”. Green aligns with the views of Thomas Chalmers (1780–1847): “There are, perhaps, no opinions more diametrically opposed to each other, than those of theorizing antiquaries. On almost every important question the contending parties, in point of numbers and reputation, neutralize themselves; and what Dr. Chalmers has said in his Evidences of Christianity relative to speculating geologists, may justly be applied to them. ‘Though our imaginations have been regaled by the brilliancy of their speculations, they are so opposite to each other, that we now cease to be impressed by their evidence’” (Astronomical Recreations, 76, 64–65).

In Discourses on the Christian Revelation Viewed in Connection with the Modern Astronomy (1817), Chalmers sought to refute skeptical arguments that the evidence of astronomy undermines the truth of Christian revelation. A copy of the Astronomical Discourses was in the Ruskin family library (Dearden, Library of John Ruskin, 67 [no. 473]). Chalmers instead proposes, according to David Cairns, “such a relevance between the knowledge which the sciences present to us”—even the presentiment by modern astronomy of a forbiddingly vast and violent universe—and the convictions of faith that Cairns deems the discourses as constituting a natural theology (“Thomas Chalmersʼ Astronomical Discourses”, 417).

As Jonathan R. Topham has carefully argued, however, evangelicals such as Chalmers were not typically receptive to the optimistic version of natural theology that William Paley (1743–1805) influentially presented, with its evidences of a benevolent Creator as watchmaker, yet many evangelicals—especially Scottish evangelicals—remained open to a “theology of nature”, which advocated “arationalreligionthatwouldattracttheculturedmiddleclasses,whilemaintainingascripturalandsoteriologicalemphasisdistinctfromthelargelyethicalemphasis”ofnatural theology.
